user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl:
```c
void OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl(osal_objtype_t idtype, uint32 attempts)
{
    OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *impl;
    struct timespec         ts;

    impl = OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[idtype];

    /*
     * because pthread_cond_timedwait() is also a cancellation point,
     * this pushes a cleanup handler to ensure that if canceled during this call,
     * the mutex will be released.
     */
    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_ReleaseTableMutex, &impl->mutex);

    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &ts);

    if (attempts <= 10)
    {
        /* Wait an increasing amount of time, starting at 10ms */
        ts.tv_nsec += attempts * attempts * 10000000;
        if (ts.tv_nsec >= 1000000000)
        {
            ts.tv_nsec -= 1000000000;
            ++ts.tv_sec;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /* wait 1 second (max for polling) */
        ++ts.tv_sec;
    }

    pthread_cond_timedwait(&impl->cond, &impl->mutex, &ts);

    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl:
OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *const OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER] = {
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED]   = NULL,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK]     = &OS_global_task_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE]    = &OS_queue_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM] = &OS_count_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM]   = &OS_bin_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX]    = &OS_mutex_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM]   = &OS_stream_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR]      = &OS_dir_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE] = &OS_timebase_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB]   = &OS_timecb_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE]   = &OS_module_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS]  = &OS_filesys_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE]  = &OS_console_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR]  = &OS_condvar_lock,
}
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mutex;
    pthread_cond_t  cond;
} OS_impl_objtype_lock_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
void OS_Posix_ReleaseTableMutex(void *mut)
{
    pthread_mutex_unlock(mut);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that modify any function parameter (either OS_WaitForStateChange_Impl's parameters idtype and attempts, or OS_Posix_ReleaseTableMutex's parameter mut). Specifically:
- idtype is only used to index OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[idtype] (read-only). There is no assignment to idtype, no increment/decrement, and its address is not taken.
- attempts is only read in the conditional and arithmetic expression (attempts * attempts * 10000000). There is no assignment to attempts, no use of ++/--, and its address is not taken.
- The pointer parameter mut in OS_Posix_ReleaseTableMutex is only forwarded to pthread_mutex_unlock(mut) and is not assigned or modified.
- No other function in the provided fragments takes a pointer parameter that is reassigned inside the function.
Therefore, there are no fragments that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
